intro: Anemopaegma chamberlaynii var. tenerior, commonly known as the woolly anemopaegma, is a rare and unique plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbel-like flower clusters. The plant is distinguished by its dense, woolly covering of hairs on its leaves and stems, which helps it retain moisture in arid environments. It produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
